item.title: Apple’s possible new case tech could reshape how you use your iPhone
item.description: Apple is reportedly testing a new kind of official iPhone case that doesn’t just protect—it interacts. According to a tip via MacRumors, the company is working on a “touch-sensitive layer” built into protective cases for upcoming Pro models.

item.title: Here’s why it’s hard to buy the ROG Xbox Ally X, and why that’s actually a good thing
item.description: The ROG Xbox Ally X is already in short supply despite its $999 price and niche category — but that’s not a disaster. In fact, it’s a strong signal: demand has out-paced ASUS’s expectations, suggesting the market for high-end handheld gaming PCs is real.

item.title: A fresh look for the Apple Watch seems way further in the future
item.description: Despite earlier reports hinting at a sleeker design and new band system in 2026, the next few generations are now expected to stick with the familiar aesthetic.

item.title: You can now buy a used Ford car with just a few clicks on Amazon
item.description: Ford has begun listing certified pre-owned cars on Amazon, letting shoppers browse, finance, and start the purchase process online with dealer-backed warranties. The program launches in select U.S. cities, giving customers a simpler way to buy used Ford vehicles through Amazon’s Auto marketplace.

item.title: After digital romance, AI companions are now triggering real-world divorces
item.description: Divorce attorneys say emotional relationships with AI chatbots are now showing up in real cases, with partners citing spending, data sharing, and deep attachment to AI companions as reasons for separation. The trend is growing quickly as chatbot interactions become more realistic and personal.

item.title: Google Play just solved a huge hassle for streaming films and TV shows
item.description: Play Store now offers a built-in card that reveals which streaming apps host your searched title, simplifying discovery and app installs.

item.title: Samsung’s Galaxy Buds 4 Pro want you to control audio with your head
item.description: Leaked One UI 8.5 animations give us our clearest look yet at Samsung’s Galaxy Buds 4 Pro, including new head-based controls, softer hardware, and a flatter case that looks built for everyday use.

item.title: Galaxy Z TriFold moves closer to your pocket with fresh US firmware tests
item.description: Samsung has reportedly started testing firmware for the unlocked Galaxy Z TriFold in the US, hinting that its first tri-fold phone might be edging toward shelves, even if the launch date and markets are not confirmed.

item.title: Your Apple Watch could face a new US import ban over $634m fight
item.description: Apple’s latest courtroom clash with Masimo now includes a $634 million verdict and a fresh US trade review, putting the Apple Watch’s blood oxygen feature and future stock of newer models under real pressure.

item.title: Your Galaxy phone can now turn selfies into AI art with Nano Banana
item.description: Samsung has added Google’s Nano Banana image-editing model to the Now Brief feature on Galaxy phones, allowing your device to automatically turn selected selfies into AI-generated art. The tool uses Google’s Gemini tech to create quick, stylized edits you can save or share.

item.title: YouTube Music is testing playlist search so you can stop endless scrolling
item.description: YouTube Music is finally testing playlist search, with a new Find in playlist button appearing for a tiny group of iOS users. It fixes one of the app’s most obvious pain points, but almost no one has it yet.

item.title: Don’t hold your hopes for a new Mac Pro coming anytime soon
item.description: A new Bloomberg report suggests Apple has quietly sidelined the Mac Pro, canceling its next Ultra chip and shifting its attention to the Mac Studio instead.

item.title: The fate of a second-gen iPhone Air may not be doomed after all
item.description: A new Bloomberg report clarifies that the next iPhone Air was never delayed and could debut in 2027 (its original schedule).

item.title: Disney channels are finally back on YouTube TV
item.description: YouTube TV and Disney resolved their carriage dispute, restoring major networks and issuing an apology.

item.title: Is this the future of housework? Watch a robot tackle chores with ease
item.description: This is one of the most impressive performances we've seen yet.

item.title: Android’s next trick could let you tap phones together to share info, just like iPhones
item.description: Google is reportedly developing a new feature, internally known as “Gesture Exchange” or “Contact Exchange,” that allows Android users to share contact details by tapping their phones together, much like NameDrop on iOS.

item.title: Window cleaning meets the final frontier as cosmonaut gets the sponge out
item.description: NASA shares a photo of a space-based window cleaner.

item.title: End of an era? Tim Cook’s exit looms for Apple leadership
item.description: Multiple reports indicate Apple is actively preparing for Tim Cook to step down as CEO as early as next year, kicking off what could be the most significant leadership transition in the company’s history.

item.title: Android 17 is getting serious about physical controllers
item.description: Google is reportedly preparing the next major Android release, Android 17, to bring mobile gaming closer to console-style experience. Leaks and reports hint at improved native controller support, built-in button remapping, and low-latency gameplay features.

item.title: I tested 4 ChatGPT prompt generators and here’s the one that helped the most
item.description: ChatGPT by itself is okay, but these prompt generators produce better results.

item.title: You Asked: Best big screen for $1,000? Smart TV apps vs. streaming devices?
item.description: Our resident TV expert Chris is here to answer all your questions, including are there TVs that won’t cause eye strain and migraines?

item.title: Smartphones might put a deeper dent in your wallet next year because of the AI race
item.description: Upstream DRAM and NAND scarcity, fueled by AI and data-center demand, is forcing mobile manufacturers to postpone purchases.

item.title: Android phones could soon get a face unlock solution that rivals Apple FaceID
item.description: Metalenz and UMC’s Polar ID mass-production deal marks the dawn of next-gen, ultra-thin, polarization-based face biometrics aimed at billions of devices, promising faster, slimmer security.

item.title: 4 things to do when you first get the OnePlus 15
item.description: OnePlus 15 is a performance powerhouse, but the more rewarding part is the OxygenOS 16 software experience that is loaded with a bunch of nifty features you will love.

item.title: Say goodbye to old DMs: X launches Chat with encryption and more
item.description: X has officially launched Chat, replacing its classic Direct Messages with a full-featured communication suite, now with end-to-end encryption, video/voice calls, file transfer and disappearing messages.

item.title: Your Disney+ experience is about to get way more interactive
item.description: Disney+ is getting a major AI makeover, letting users create short films, play game-like experiences, and interact with iconic Disney worlds in new, creative ways.

item.title: You can now share your favorite Amazon Music tracks and playlists on TikTok
item.description: Amazon Music is adding a new “Share to TikTok” feature that lets you post songs, playlists, and listening stats directly into TikTok. The update makes it easier to show what you’re listening to and turn your music moments into shareable content.
